clues.text: The cynics revered this hero whose 12 labors were an example of a moral victory & self-liberation
Spartan leader Lysander defeated this rival Greek city & established the government of the thirty tyrants over it
Protagoras is famous for the quote this "is the measure of all things"
In the 1870s the first monument archaeologists dug out at this site was the Temple of Zeus
Archimedes was from this Sicilian city, in his time the greatest Greek city in the west
English title of Jean Cocteau's haunting "La Belle et la Bete", which had no singing teapots
1947's "Out of the Past" unfolds largely through this technique, a look into the past
Name shared by Orson Welles' character in "Jane Eyre" & Eddie Anderson's in "Buck Benny Rides Again"
Ray Milland played  an alcoholic terrorized by a hallucinatory bat  in this 1945 film
In this movie "of 1940", Fred Astaire danced with Eleanor Powell, an alumna of the versions of '36 & '38
"God Separating the Light from Darkness" is one of the major scenes Michelangelo painted here
In 1912 this 30-year-old Spaniard began incorporating business cards & wallpaper into his paintings
The setting of this "American Gothic" artist's "Midnight Ride of Paul Revere" looks like Iowa, not Boston
This "Night Cafe" artist worked for art dealers Goupil & Co. until 1876 when he was forced out
Beginning in 1728, this British satirist painted a scene from "The Beggar's Opera" in several versions
In 1926 this cowboy humorist's newspaper column went from weekly to daily
In 1974 his show "A Prairie Home Companion" debuted on 30 Midwest public radio stations
Charles Farrar used the name Artemus Ward for his humorous pieces in this Cleveland paper
Copying "Naked Came the Stranger", Dave Barry & 12 others created this novel on the installment plan
This author of "A Book of Nonsense" is considered a master of the limerick
To carefully arrange one's fur, feathers or clothing
The head of government of a Canadian province
Term for a novel written after another one, but depicting earlier events
If I said "Jeopardy!" winnings are exempt from U.S. taxes, I'd be doing this, which means lying
The story of this distance runner of the 1970s came to the big screen in 1997
William Wallace (Mel Gibson) wants to free the Scots from the tyranny of the English in this Oscar-winning film
In "The Greatest Showman", Hugh Jackman played this larger-than-life impresario
She was I, Tonya (Harding) & Elizabeth I in "Mary Queen of Scots"
Game theory mathematician John Nash was the subject of this biopic
"Walk the Line" starred Joaquin Phoenix as Johnny Cash & her as June Carter
Gilbert & Sullivan's first work together was "Thespis", about a group of actors who take over this home of the Greek gods
At the start of this operetta, a chorus of nobles sings, "If you want to know who we are, we are gentlemen of Japan"
In "The Pirates of Penzance" it's the rank of an army officer named Stanley; in fact he's the very model of a modern one
In an 1889 operetta that begins in Venice, Marco & Giuseppe are 2 of these title boatmen
Despite never having been to sea, Sir Joseph Porter is "rule of the queen's navee" in this shipshape favorite
Brigham Young's grave is there; at the foot of the Wasatch Range; somehow known for its jazz
Home to 20 million; used to be synonymous with sailor kidnappings; has its name on a 128-story tower
Inhale the scents of the Fragrance Museum; 25 miles from Dusseldorf; see the 15th c. art of Stefan Lochner
Had the Olympics; locals call a seasonal stiff wind the "southerly buster" & a big local bridge, the Coat Hanger
A world capital; on the shore of the RÃ­o de la Plata; has a stadium called "The Cathedral of Polo"
Effusive & lively, perhaps after a glass of champagne
Smiling with happiness, or emitting rays of light
This adjective meaning "charitable" is the "B" in BPOE, the full name of the Elks Lodge
This Scottish adjective means attractive, like many a lass or a particular prince
Did you inherit some money? You were the recipient of this from someone's will

"Finders Keepers"--the first book was "Mr. Mercedes"

Appropriately, noted clockmaker Aaron Willard was one of these colonial militiamen
WWII Medal of Honor recipient John Basilone, who served in the Philippines in the 1930s, had this "capital" nickname

In this system of equalizing the burden horses carry to make a race fair, an impost is an added weight
In "A Wrinkle in Time", Meg's scientist dad likes to extend "Meg" into this nickname  equal to 3.26 million light years
From the Greek for "interpreter", this plural word is the branch of theology dealing with the interpretation of biblical texts

rounds.text: With over 2 million people, it's the largest city in the West Indies
